intro: Quercus robur subf. hiemalis, commonly known as the winter oak, is a subspecies of the common oak characterized by its distinctive botanical features. It is a deciduous tree that typically reaches heights of 15–25 meters, with a broad, spreading crown. The leaves are lobed and have a serrated margin, turning yellow in autumn before falling. Its acorns are small and often have a cupule that covers most of the nut. This subspecies is adapted to colder climates, showcasing its resilience to harsh winter conditions.
